endTime.description: The end time of the session.

notes.description: Any notes related to the session.

learningObjectives.description: List of things a mentee will learn.

setupRequirements.description: Any technical or other setup requirements.

UniqueSession.description: Represents a unique session offering created by the admin.

id.description: Unique identifier for the unique session.

title.description: The title of the unique session.

description.description: A description of the unique session.

cost.description: The cost of the unique session.

Tip.description: Represents a tip or resource for mentees.

summary.description: A brief summary of the tip.

content.description: The full content of the tip (for articles).

link.description: The URL for the tip (for YouTube/Website).

Coupon.title: Coupon
Coupon.description: Represents a redeemable coupon for adding balance.

id.description: The coupon code itself, used as the document ID.

amount.description: The monetary value of the coupon.

expiresAt.description: The expiration date of the coupon.

isUsed.description: Whether the coupon has already been redeemed.

PendingPayment.description: Represents a payment submission awaiting manual verification.

id.description: Unique identifier for the payment request.

userId.description: The ID of the user who submitted the payment.

transactionId.description: The bKash transaction ID provided by the user.

status.description: The verification status of the payment.

BalanceTransaction.title: BalanceTransaction
BalanceTransaction.description: Represents a transaction that affects a user's balance.

amount.description: The transaction amount (can be positive or negative).

description.description: A human-readable description of the transaction.

MentorApplication.title: MentorApplication
MentorApplication.description: Represents an application from a user wanting to become a mentor.

SupportRequest.title: SupportRequest
SupportRequest.description: Represents a support request from a user.

details.description: The details of the support issue.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to securely manage admins, mentors, mentees, sessions, unique session offerings, and personalized recommendations within the MentorVerse application. The structure emphasizes authorization independence, clarity, and scalability.

Authorization Independence (CRITICAL): To avoid hierarchical authorization dependencies (`get()`), the design denormalizes authorization context where necessary. For example, access to sessions within a mentee's profile does not require fetching the mentee's profile to verify ownership. Instead, the session document itself contains the `menteeId`. Similarly, global roles (admin) are managed via a combination of custom claims on the user's authentication token and an explicit `/admins` collection.

Structural Segregation (Homogeneous Security Posture): The structure segregates data based on access needs.  User-owned data is stored under the `/users/{userId}` path, allowing for simple path-based ownership rules. Admin-created unique sessions are stored in a separate collection, `/unique_sessions`. Admin user documents are stored in `/admins`.

Access Modeling (Standardization and Consistency): The structure uses consistent patterns for authorization:
*   Private Data: Path-Based ownership is enforced for mentee-specific data (e.g., sessions under `/users/{menteeId}/sessions/{sessionId}`).
*   Global Roles (Custom Claims + Collection Check): Admin privileges are checked via `request.auth.token.admin == true` and by checking for the user's existence in the `/admins` collection.

QAPs (Rules are not Filters): The structure supports secure `list` operations by ensuring that collections contain documents with homogeneous security requirements. For example, listing sessions is secure because access to each session is determined by the path (user-owned) and/or role, not by filtering based on document content.

Invariants: The structure enforces data integrity by leveraging path-based ownership to ensure that mentees can only access their own sessions and recommendations. Timestamps are used to maintain the order and history of recommendations.
